Posts.Content: Hi rach yes thats a good way of descring it its still there now and 1st treatment was april, not sure if it will ever go! Could you ring your unit or bcn tomorrow  to discuss prior to hour consultant  appt as its cutting it fine for your next treatment? Best of luck x
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi, has no one suggested a line eg picc? I only had 1 fec via a cannula as there wasnt time to get the picc in and that damaged the vein badly its corded and difficult to straighten sometimes, my unit recommended massaging along the vein which helped s bit.  Dont know how anyone gets through chemo without one! X
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi, has no one suggested a line eg picc? I only had 1 fec via a cannula as there wasnt time to get the picc in and that damaged the vein badly its corded and difficult to straighten sometimes, my unit recommended massaging along the vein which helped s bit.  Dont know how anyone gets through chemo without one! X
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi rach yes thats a good way of descring it its still there now and 1st treatment was april, not sure if it will ever go! Could you ring your unit or bcn tomorrow  to discuss prior to hour consultant  appt as its cutting it fine for your next treatment? Best of luck x
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi i was diagnosed in january and had surgery, chemo and rads finished beginning of october.  Iam going back to work on Monday and to be honest its taken me till now to feel back to whatever the new normal is. I work for the nhs and only have a 2 week phased return (generous!) So will be using annual leave to work partime for a bit. I am lucky that i have a generally office based role as i couldnt do anything really physical at the moment.  Good luck xx
Posts.Title: Returning to work? How soon?

Posts.Content: Oh bless  you that is a wait! I was diagnosed  1/2 after being referred  back to the breast clinic  in December,  bit complicated  with a fair few biopsies.  The guidance is that  treatment starts within 31 days  of diagnoses and you will probably find  things move  a bit quicker now. This is a really hard time but will get better when things move forward and you have a plan xxx
Posts.Title: waiting and more waiting :(

Posts.Content: Thank you Julia, just having a morbid moment when I realised I wasn't sure . 'X
Posts.Title: Question about survival stats

Posts.Content: Probably sounds daft but when looking at 1, 5, 10 yr survival  stats is this from 1st diagnosis or end of treatment (not including hormone therapy)? X
Posts.Title: Question about survival stats

Posts.Content: Hi Jane first off just to well done for getting this far  and thank you for posting as I am sure it's helpful to those at a similar point as you and for those a bit behind.   Although as lacomtemp I am not as far down the line as you I  (and I am sure many others) can relate to how you are feeling. I was diagnosed last January and had wle, couple nodes emoved,  chemo and rads which finished october and I feel very strange about it all.  In some ways it feels like it happened to someone else and I feel in some ways I managed on my own as hubby couldn't cope with my cancer and both he and the kids (10 yr old) think it's all over and done with and iam back to normal and iam not, the anastrozole  is horrible (and iam to scared to change in case that's worse) and I am still stiff and painful after the rads. I also think of others whose are in a worse place and feel guilty.  I have just had my first mammogram after treatment and I think this has stirred things up in my mind also. When reading through things it seems our feelings are very common it's just that it's to hard (in the main) for our nearest and dearest to understand how it affects us and to be fair I don't think people who have not been in this position ever can and to some extent we bob along with them and turn to safe places like this forum when we need to. I am also interested  in the to the thing also as since chemo I lost a bit of one tooth and the enamel off another 2! Sending a giant hug xxxxx
Posts.Title: Feeling strange 1 year after chemo

Posts.Content: Woo hoo that's great Londonlass, as the risk of sounding like my nanny everything feels better after a good night's sleep xxx
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Awh sorry you are having a crap time but glad you're'd GP has been a bit more proactive.  My GP started me on amitriptyline alongside the strong cocodamol acouple of weeks ago and i notice the difference if I don't take it (when i gave couple of medicinal wines lol). I have been taking it a bit earlier rather than when I go to bed as don't feel as fuzzy in the morning.  Hope it improves things for you I really think the effect of chronic pain is underestimated  {{{hug}}} xx
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Must admit julia that's one of the other things I have thought about  even though the evidence isn't there it is at the back of my mind.
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Yvonne, I have been wrestling with this since last week as I start fec t next week.   After much thinking I have decided  not to go for it for all the reasons  you've said and I feel so much better for making the descion. Have to say it's my eyebrows that worry me more  so I am off to get a semi permanent pair  .
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Great news londonlass lo g may it continue :) xx
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Arh rats londonlass, however it is a positive start?  Iam not to bad  thank you the amitriptyline  had helped  the pain of the AI just a bit brassed  off at feeling 90 at 49 but till kicking and breathing  so every  cloud  lol xxx
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Hi mand123, I start Fec-t on 6th April and have been debating this one non stop since onc appointment  last week! Weighing it all up I don't *think* i am going to go for it. I am not sure i want to invest any more time sitting in hospital feeling grotty for hair that i will need to get cut much shorter, will thin (maybe come out anyway) and possinly still need a wig.  I also get  horrendous  tension migraine and the thought of that kicking off on top makes me feel quite ill.  I possibly would feel slightly different  if I hadn't seen my mum go through chemo for  lymphoma, her wig was fantastic and we begged her to keep it rather than grow hers back  (she didn't lol). I think it's a really personal descion as I know there are many ladies  who it worked well. However  if there are some starting treatment where oncologists  are not recommending it they need to explain why so people can make an informed choice. All that said I may change my mind in the next week . I do know  that losing my eyebrows really does bother me and I am getting semi permanent ones done .
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Hi Ann,  i had my 1st fec on wednesdsy and was s $! $$&g myself beforehand has been said it us the unknown.  I couldnt have drove home as I felt a bit muzzy headed  afterwards and didn't feel to bad till about 5 hrs later when I was headaches and felt  sick,  I will go to bed earlier next  time.  Have felt but grim the last couple of days  but not unmanagable and up and showered just very tired. Everyone is different. Good luck.x
Posts.Title: CHEMO TO START

Posts.Content: I am so sorry  you are in this position and don't have much to offer apart from the fact that my very recent diagnosis started as microcalcifications  which has taken 6mths, 4 biopsies, numerous mammograms to find! I am waiting for lump echoey and sentinel node bioosy but my biggest fear is that it was so hard to find how will they no where to look ,what to take out and what if they haven't found it all . Best of luck for Tuesday x
Posts.Title: Terrified..MX on Tuesday

Posts.Content: www.associationofbreastsurgery.org.uk/.../  Just to say that although nice hasn't been updated  (although the quality standard  has which includes oncotype testing) the association of breast surgeons dies have a consensus  statement on management of the axilla, plus a few other useful things eg biphosphinate.  Link above.  X
Posts.Title: I dont want a Total Axial Node Clearance - what are my options?

Posts.Content: Good luck for your appointment as carolynn says you have up until they knock you out so bit of time left :). I am halfway through radiotherapy at the moment and do wonder on occassion whether i made the right decision but it was an informed one and is one i can live with xxx
Posts.Title: I dont want a Total Axial Node Clearance - what are my options?

Posts.Content: Hi Bunty Ann,  i had 3rd fec (start t next) last week and whilst it's not high on my wish list of things to do and I have felt rough at times  but its doable.  If i were asked would I do it again knowing what i know now the answer would still be yes, good luck x
Posts.Title: Chemo consult

Posts.Content: Hi Cathy's I think this is one you really need to discuss with your surgeon  so you are clear about all options to allow you to make an informed decision. What I would say is that treatment to the axilla seems contentious and varies by centre! I was diagnosed in January with grade 2, stage 2 idc with 1/2 nodes (macromet) affected on snb (3 week wait for results!!) Which was a bit of a shock as it wasn't seen on ultrasound and i am presuming you are the same. I finished chemotherapy  begining of August and due to start rads which after much debating with oncologist and surgeon i went for rads to the axilla rather than clearance. My surgeon was quite adamant that clearance would not improve survival and although there was a risk of lymphodeoma with radiotherapy that long term issues where much higher with clearance.  I aldo spoke to the macmillan advice line who were very helpful. Good luck with your descion x
Posts.Title: I dont want a Total Axial Node Clearance - what are my options?

Posts.Content: Glad you are out of hospital and hope you are feeling better each day xxxxx
Posts.Title: THANKYOU SO MUCH

Posts.Content: Palmers concentrated cream (not the hand cream one) fabulous stuff x
Posts.Title: Hand Cream

Posts.Content: Mine has also grown back nanas perm style but I have had 3-4 trims now and it has calmed down a bit . I have also kept the grey as I quite like it and have found Tigi texturising paste is fab it defines/separates the curl nicely.  Xx
Posts.Title: Curly Hair!

Posts.Content: I have done 13 months on anastrozole  and it has been awful I have lived on strong painkillers, exhausted and a brain like candy floss, i am only 50!.  Although I attributed some of the pain etc to the anastrozle I thought that it was also after effects of chemo as i couldnt believe 1 tablet could make you feel so awful! I saw my oncologist last week and he agreed to a 4 week break and to try again, if that didn't do anything he suggested exemestane. After 4 days off it I felt bloody fantastic like the pre chemo me, i will give exemestane  a go but i have decided to stop if the side effects are the same and take my chance with the cancer xx
Posts.Title: Stopping Anastrazole early - advice please

Posts.Content: Think i posted some thing similar after finishing chemo in august! I found i couldnt use "ordinary" shampoo and switchec to sls, paraben free products palmers do a great moisturizing  shampoo and scalp n hair conditioner it isnt dear and i buy  it on 3 for 2 in superdrug sukin is also good xxx
Posts.Title: Dry, flaky, itch scalp since chemo.

Posts.Content: Oh how frustrating for you! Not a lot to add to what  has already been said  other than to agree that I would wait for the results as you can't make an informed decision  at this point without them. Sending a hug and hope you aren't waiting to much longer x
Posts.Title: Scared about today

Posts.Content: Oh now, do sorry you are now dealing with thus  we lost 2 of our greyhounds to  to bone and liver  cancer it all just seems do unfair.  It's heartbreaking,  take care x
Posts.Title: What is it with cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi jen, I can think of a million more exciting ways to be attention seeking than having breast cancer, in fact i think you need to start to make a list of all the wonderful things you can do the other side of treatment lol! My 10 year old daughter is very  keen  on pointing out/wanting to go into Cancer research shops  bless her,  I just go with the flow cos as you say she sees it differently my hubby just looks uncomfortable and he is 100% supportive so even the best of them struggle at times. X
Posts.Title: Husband remark to cancer

Posts.Content: Mand,  this is a crappy,  s&^%=y time for you.  I am waiting  for my post op results,  everything indicates chemo not required  but radiotherapy  and 10 year hormone therapy but am worried that this will change.  Chemo not great but if my team recommend  then I will go for it,  if no great benefit then I will take their advice.  Wishing you  the best of luck xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling overwhelmed!

Posts.Content: Oh Bev, I am so glad you posted this .  I lost 2.5 st (wwould have been 3 but didn't shift the 1/2 st gained during the all you can trough all inclusive, then all this kicked off december) and haven't been this weight in over 25 yes and am devastated st the thought of weight gain as all my fat clothes are gone!  However, my family keeps telling me that there are more important things and it doesn't matter but it does to me, it's just another crap thing at a crap time. Don't get me wrong I am a size 14 not 8 but I like the 14. I am also toying with the idea of suspending my gym membership for a bit, Zumba is my thing (i like insanity but think that's a bit optimistic! ) rather than the gym but wasn't sure if it's going to be a waste of money to keep it going?
Posts.Title: Weight gain on chemo

Posts.Content: Dreamthief just had a quick look that was quite enough lol x
Posts.Title: HRT study results

Posts.Content: Grrrŕ, rant away you are not being over emotional at all. I think a lot of men suffer from ostrich syndrome thinking it situations will go away  if ignored rather than dealing with things. Is he normally  like this  or just  being a super ostrich  at the moment? Either way he needs to find a way of dealing with it both for you and him.  I agree with  Fiona you do think you need to be able to talk to others for support and I think this is the same whether or not partners are super or need a bit of a shake as sometimes it gets a bit intense  if there is no outside support to bring you back from the dark places of the mind and sometimes to chivvy you along and get a grip when everything seems to be spiralling out of control which happens to the strongest of  us. Sending hugs x
Posts.Title: Husband remark to cancer

Posts.Content: I will second that debenhams  seem to gave have a much better range of non wired bras than m&s, enjoy your  hollibobs x
Posts.Title: Bras - rant!!!!

Posts.Content: Mmm, when i started on hrt all the % i had seen/was quoted related to women 50 +. In my mind the fairly low % and the fact that i had an early menopause at 44 low dose hrt was a replacement for naturally occuring oestrogen. What i wasnt told was that i could have had eoestrogen only hrt as i had a mirena coil. My bc was er 6 and pr 8 so i am always wondering now how big a part the hrt and mirena played? Is there a link to the study or just the news item?
Posts.Title: HRT study results

Posts.Content: Hi, I had wle, mammoplasty and sentinel node biopsy 2 weeks ago and left my hair to dry the first week as I had a horrendous  viral chest thing and felt to unwell to follow anything else. I ha very thick hair which takes some drying and was fine  (just took a bit longer) after that just  keep on doing the exercises  or it really stiffens up x
Posts.Title: Trying to be practical

Posts.Content: Well you learn something new everyday my dog had standard booster and kennel cough when was having chemo and noone mentioned anythinh :,
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and my dog

Posts.Content: Oh Skye,  really feel for you although I feel our families maybe related lol, lol. My mum is 69 and has "enjoyed" ill health following her own cancer diagnosis  (17 years remission now) and had no interest in anything related to my breast cancer apart from telling me that everyone she knows has been fine and theirs was 20 years ago  (helpful not!) and my siblings are useless, if it hadn't been for my in laws we would have been stuffed.  I was in hospital twice for a week with neutropenic  sepsis and was visited once,  the 2nd time in laws were away and friends/mums from school helped out not family.  You are not moaning at all it is very upsetting,  reading back this post it probably isn't helpful to you other than to say your not on your own  and to send a you massive cyber hug xxxx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Skye, good luck for today hope everything works itself out.  If not totally the one thing I have learnt is sometimes it's just not worth wasting energy on some things/people use it to focus on yourself,  little one and lovely friends as there will be an end to this horrible  time xx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Good luck going back i returned to work in january after being diagnosed jan 16 had surgery, chemo and radiotherapy.   I work for yhe nhs and our policy is 2 weeks phased return (!) So i had to use annual leave to extend it but i dont think that they can do a forced reduction.   Xxx
Posts.Title: Back to work anxiety

Posts.Content: @Nickf just wanted to say my surgeon (and mdt) thought RT was the best plan unfortunately  my oncologist who was in the mdt started suggesting mastectomy and clearance after chemo which was frustrating as well as unexpected! I went back to discuss with my surgeon who was very clear that clearance wasn't required although he would do it if i wanted. I decided to have RT after the oncologist agreed that there wasnt a right or wrong decision and if he felt that it had have been wrong in my situation he would have told me that.  I can live with the decision i made and thats the key thing to bear in mind xx
Posts.Title: Received Lumpectomy Results, 2 sentinel nodes have cancer - what happens...

Posts.Content: Hi badgerbam, i was in a similar position this time last year following routine screening that threw up some calcification.  It was suppose to be small and simple with no nodes affected but turned out to be a 3cm invasive cancer that had  also gone to a sentinal node which was a huge shock. My surgeon was very clear that radiotherapy to the armpit rather than clearance was the appropriate way forward as Nick has said it seems to vary by centre but very much standard practice in the US. I did have chemo followed by radiotherapy and last year is a bit of a blur but i am now back at work. Whilst you would always hope for clear nodes it definately doesnt mean that it has spread elsewhere and it certainly isnt a death sentance. You have to put your faith in the clinical team to give you the best info to make an informed decision xxc
Posts.Title: Received Lumpectomy Results, 2 sentinel nodes have cancer - what happens...

Posts.Content: Fiddlesticks I really feel for you. As julia has said there is no set timeframes it's generally down to the employer and "reasonable" adjustments in conjunction with OH were there is one. I work in public sector and will have 2 weeks phased return and then have to use annual leave, i am trying to plan going back to work beginning  of december and am stressing about coping (chemo finished August, rads October)and am struggling with joint/muscle pain from the anastrozle. Reading this have realised that iam not offering any help (lol) but can really empathise with your position!
Posts.Title: How long can I stay on a phased return/reduced duties?

Posts.Content: You have my sympathy ive been on anastozrole since September  and the joint/muscle/bone pain has been horrendous although the sweats have improved alot.  Ive had accord and teva and havent noticed any difference.  I had fec, tax then paclitaxel and had neuropathy which got worse when treatment finishe (apparently its called coasting) my gp started me on amitriptyline and if i dont take it the muscle pain etc is much worse so i dont know if some of it is actually linked to the chemo? I mentioned it on my post rads review but got the impression its considered a minor effect and they said i could change to another ai but iam to scared in case its worse, I am 49 and feel 90!!  Xx
Posts.Title: Femara ( Letrozole) V Arimidex ( Anastrozole) advice please !!!

Posts.Content: Hi and welcome,the chemo bag is a lovely idea :).  I had fec t (finished with paclicataxol so extended it a bit) and went to all treatmemt on my own. My sil used to drop me off and pick me up,i hate fuss and just couldn't stand the thought of sitting there making small talk with someone or us both looking at tablets /reading,didnt see much point.  What i really appreciated was help afterwards eg looking after kids, help in the house,listening ear etc when i felt grotty that is what got me and hubby through.  Good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Daughters 1st chemo

Posts.Content: My personal view is that its a barbaric practice to give via vein i had 1 as there wasn't time to get a picc in for the first treatment and you can still see were the vein was damaged 9 months later. Had no problems with picc but as has been said its personal choice. Xx
Posts.Title: Cannula vs PICC vs Port??

Posts.Content: PICC line all the way , my vein was ruined after 1st fec as it couldn't be put in  in time,  so much easier and just bought a limbo cover for the shower. Don't know how  anyone  gets hrough chemo without  one (or other  port etc) x
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: Flipping  heck  Fiona Ive only had a had a 10 minute whinge throughout this horrible journey and your post had sent me to the tissues! Firstly congratulations in making it to this point as others have said you have been so supportive on the forum so a big, big thank you and to say that you do look great but I understand where you are coming from. It's such a gruelling journey one way and another that there are still baby steps to take when coming out on the other side. Big hugs xxx
Posts.Title: A bit of a ramble....and a thank you!

Posts.Content: Hi jammy Fiona,  haven't much to add to that already posted but it does seem to be a common feeling of somewhat  feeling cut adrift following treatment. Do need to say though how fantastic you look ,. Xxx
Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly no  wonder you are fed up, I have no expierience  if metasin testing  but flopsy has given some info. I had 1 macrometastasis in lymph node  and my surgeon recommended axilla  radiotherapy rather than clearance would this be an option for discussion uf the cancer deposit  was small and not detected by snb?
Posts.Title: Metasin Testing

Posts.Content: Absolutely recommend it. I had 1 fec via a cannula  as there wasn't time to get picc in and I have  been left with a damaged vein  which is extremely painful when I extend my arm. X
Posts.Title: PICC Line - yes or no?

Posts.Content: Flippin heck don't remember anyone going into that much detail! I have had 15 sessions an 1 of 8 boosts this morning, apart from an itchy rash on my chest which they've given me hydrocortisone  cream for, pink boob/nipple with the odd pain and a bit of a stiff arm which all in all are minor things it's all been fine so far and none if the ladies I've spoken to have had anything horrendous.  Bit over the top if you ask me she could have given you the same info in a way that wouldn't frighten the pants off x
Posts.Title: Rads - Panic?

Posts.Content: Happy birthday to youuu , I thinking your sell by date is a way off yet lol lol xxxx
Posts.Title: Advice on Pain Relief...

Posts.Content: I am one of those unfortunate people  who likes to know the ins and outs of everthing  (drives hubby mad! ). After much chasing  (again) I have finally had copies of the letters of the last 3  months oncology appointments were it now updated to say I am weakly er+. My tumour was er 6/8 & pr 8/8, her - . Whilst i understand that 8/8 is highly er + i didn't realise 6 was considered weak, does this mean that it has a higher chance of reoccurrence as the anastrozle isn't very effective? I was 48 and post menopausal on diagnosis is the score generally lower post menopause? I start anastrozle  next week and am cross the oncologist hasnt dixcussed this, I don't see him till after rads now so it's started me on a new worry fest.
Posts.Title: Weak er +?

Posts.Content: I would ask the oncologist as you are seeing them sooner although they may say see your gp.  There is scope for jigging them (i am not suggesting trying any of this without discussing with gp/oncologist), you can take tramodol in the day or try the stronger cocodamol.  My situation is different but after taking tramodol for pain from taxane/anastrozole i switched to amitriptline  at night with stronger cocodamol during the day which doesnt take it away totally but makes it manageable.   Good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Advice on Pain Relief...

Posts.Content: Eek karen just seen your post about paracetamol  and tramodol as this is what my gp prescribed when i was taking it. X
Posts.Title: Advice on Pain Relief...

Posts.Content: Baki,  I can't imagine the emotions that are rampaging around your head at the moment no wonder your courage, energy and anything else have temporarily wandered off for a bit! As with most things no one can make decisions or plan about/for whatever  without having information and you are in that awful place of nothingness at present. Thinking of you and hoping the PET scan goes well today x Helen
Posts.Title: Devastated breast cancer recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi, I can't fault the nhs care that i have had and don't believe I would have had better if I had private care.  You don't have all the full information until the results of the surgery  are back as grade, stage etc may change at this point, I am sure if the mdt thought it clinically  appropriate  then a ct would have been recommended prior to surgery. However, it is whatever you feel comfortable with. I only waited 24 days for surgery and thus was because I required 2 further biopsies  and had to wait gfofrum the results.
Posts.Title: Private or NHS care/treatment decision

Posts.Content: I can empathise with him as i ended up on weekly taxol after ending up on weekly treatment due to 2 hospital stays with sepsis.  As has already been said surgery is the main treatment for breast cancer the chemo and radiotherapy are the belt and braces approach to reduce the che chance if it recurring.  It feels very strange when you at come to the end of active treatment and are "cut free" and it can feel quite over whelping.   Talk to the oncologist about what follow up will look like and your dad needs to become familiar how things look and feel after treatment and flag any concern, lumps, bumps quickly.  Good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Male Breast Cancer- chemo then what?!

Posts.Content: Hi pixie I developed awful shoulder pain and ended up seeing a breast physio which really helped, I still have to do arm excercises a year after rt or it stiffens up. Xx
Posts.Title: Shoulder/neck pain 2 months after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: My shoulder (affected side) started to get quire painful during radiotherapy (15 + 8 boosters) and I put it down to the funny position it was in during treatment. At post rads review in November  was told to keep doing the exercises. Had an appointment with my fab BCN recently who referred me to the physio and have had a few sessions and it's really helping but a bit pissed off that I was fobbed off and now have more of a problem than I needed to, ask to be referred xx
Posts.Title: Aches and pains ....... still!!!

Posts.Content: Awh sorry you had a tough time. Whilst I wouldn't say I sailed through fec it was easier than taxotere for me and i ended up in hospital on 1st ans 2nd tax despite the injections and changed to weekly Paclitaxol instead of the last tax. Good luck for Tuesday xxx
Posts.Title: Oh Boy ! Fell At The First Taxotere Hurdle !!

Posts.Content: Funny that Fiona tomato soup  seems to be my thing also!  Lynn hope everything went OK today x
Posts.Title: Chemo Starts Tomorrow

Posts.Content: I finished chemo in august and have a fairly good (if a bit wooly looking!) Covering of hair. I hahowever, i have got a very dry, flaky, itchy scalp. I am using paraben, sle free shampoo but does anyone have any  suggestions of what to put on it as i dont want to irritate it further? X
Posts.Title: Hair coming back - dry scalp

Posts.Content: I have only binned the scarves 3-4 weeks ago so maybe that is something to do with it?  iam off to investigate  moogoo thank you.
Posts.Title: Hair coming back - dry scalp

Posts.Content: I've had 2 so far with no real side effects.   I think this us very much a postcode lottery as I don't pay but I know some in other areas do which is quite disgraceful! X
Posts.Title: Zoledronic Acid

Posts.Content: Absolutely  agree Karen. I am moving to weekly Paclitaxol after 2 docetaxol as it made me neutropenic very quickly, that was just me it can happen with any chemotherapy regime.  I am nearly at the end now and looking back if I were asked would I have it again the answer would be yes, I want the best chance of the cancer not coming back and put my trust in the oncologist to give me the best regime and manage any side effects (which every chemotherapy drug has the potential to cause) if they occur. In my view it's no worse than other chemotherapy it's just that some of the potential side effects are different as has been said many people do not have a problem. Helen
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Yep felt like they had been trapped in a door quite sore ! I finished chemo in august and luckily i havent lost any nails. I wore coloured  nail envy on fingers and it did look like i smoked 100 fags a day with a white line for each treatment, i wore dark polish on toes and have just about got away with them not coming off  but they felt sore also xxxx
Posts.Title: Nails on 'T'

Posts.Content: Hi Maria, my oncologist raised it as an option at the initial appointment so I would say if it isn't raised do ask.  I ended up having 8 rather than 6 due to changing to Taxol and didn't manage to get the line in in time for the 1st fec,  the vein is ruined.
Posts.Title: Chemo every week for 12 weeks Taxol

Posts.Content: Grab the line with both hands I can't understand anyone who doesn't have line /port for chemo (my personal opinion!).  I had  2 docetaxol  before changing to weekly taxol x3 and whilst it's a pain going every week I found it far more tolerable than docetaxol and talking with others I met this seems to be generally the case. Good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo every week for 12 weeks Taxol

Posts.Content: Ah terri i am so sorry you have been so poorly on Docataxol, i ended up in hospital with neutropenic  sepsis twice and my oncologist switched me to weekly Paclitaxol instead of the 3rd docetaxol which was easier. Your nearly there now good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Nearing the end but dreading last one!!!

Posts.Content: Brilliant news xxx
Posts.Title: More shrinkage on 'T' chemo.

Posts.Content: Oh there's nothing more infuriating  than being fobbed off (no reason at all the bcn couldn't have given you the contact details or arranged a call  back from her senior). After my surgery I was contacted late afternoon to cancel the following  mornings appointment for the definitive results as the path report wasn't ready, I was furious as this turned 2 weeks waiting into 3, apparently  the pathologist told ghe mdt they were "just not ready"  and the surgeon wasn't happy about it so at least I didn't feel fobbed off.  The first thing I did was check the date on the path report when I got it  and it was true!  Much better to be open and honest even if it's not what us as patients want to hear it cayses much less frustration all round.  X
Posts.Title: Serously not impressed...

Posts.Content: Nothing helpful for tonight  but I have acupjncture when my back is bad maybe worth a shot? Xxx
Posts.Title: Ideas on coping with backache....

Posts.Content: Hi sorry you are having to go back for more surgery due to the margins.    I amslightly the other way round in that I got cear  margins  but a much bigger tumour than originally thought  as 15mm turned out to be 30mm (+ a further 4 mm dcis) and a positive sentinal  node whose size  just made it a macrometastasis the 2nd node was clear.   It is grade 2, er+ , her -.  My breast surgeon recommended  radiotherapy rather than further surgery  due to the increased risk of complication and with good evidence  that  it is equally effective which I was happy with. When I saw the oncologist in my case chemo was recommended, plus he wanted to discuss mastectomy (i have micro calcs in another area in the breast)and axillary clearance which we have agreed to park the discussion for a bit. As someone had said you need to now how the nodes are affected, whether it a trace if cells, etc to make an informed decision  Good luck
Posts.Title: Results of surgery

Posts.Content: Thank you to everyone who replied , julia you were right I think the decision had been made I just needed to hear that I wasn't being pathetic from others to be able to rationalise and take forward. I hate doing a substandard anything and I know deep down I can't perform to what would make me happy.  I spoke to my union yesterday also  which was useful and realise I can't change whatever happens going forward and if iam really honest I don't actually care, this has been such a wake up call the rest doesn't seem to matter as much I just feel for my team as I won't be able to support them but bless them thought I was mad for considering coming back. I also want to have some quality time in my "good" week with my children/hubby it's hard for them to watch you I'll but they seem to cope better knowing you aren't like that all the time. We both walked up to collect them from after school club  yesterday and they were do excited,  the little things hey.
Posts.Title: work or not?

Posts.Content: Jen72 I was planning to work, but I have chemo fog where my brain is slush and I am only on day 3 of my first chemo.  I felt so nausea on Friday evening, though was not sick. Feeling better today, even though I already want to go to bed.  I thought cancer was covered by disability equality or do the NHS have different rules. If you don't/can't work they I say don't.  Have you got an HR department or union you can go for advice. Jen :-) Jen, hope your feeling a bit better I found the first 5 days where a big of a right off, take care x
Posts.Title: work or not?

Posts.Content: Sorry  thus is a bit if a ramble and i know this is a question only I can answer but it's one of those  I want to fling out there as I am feeling a bit pathetic!   I have always worked full time and apart from when I had my feet done and I had a terrible bad back when pregnant  with my twins have never been signed off sick.  The bc was a horrible bolt from the blue, I had a very prolonged journey  before diagnosis but I carried on working full time until I had my surgery end of feb.  I thought I may work from home 2nd week, go in 3rd week following  chemo however after the my first chemo  I think I've changed my mind. 13 days post fec am still very fatigued but don't feel to bad. I work in the nhs and the last year has been horrendous  due to mat not covered due to cost cutting , my team are lovely but my post has been in a precarious position due to pay banding and the need to cut cost and I have found out that there are further changes which may mean I don't have a post to go back to or at am lower band.  I am lucky  that I get full pay for 6 months and whilst I didn't have critical illness cover (dam) I do have insurance which will cover any short fall if I go into/2 pay. The role is very challenging and mentally I don't think I can cope especially  when I will have no influence over future changes despite reassurances I do (for the past year i have watched a colleague being covertly bullied out of the organisation).  My hubby fully supports me not hoping back till chemo is finished. Physically  I don't know if I can/want to spend the last week of my treatment cycle trying to manage work mentally i dont think i can and I really feel pathetic when I read about people who have a few days off and work through chemo  (really admire them though) as i didnt expect to feel like this.
Posts.Title: work or not?

Posts.Content: Forgot to add it's a bloody scary position to be in so totally understand where your coming from, iam still trying to work through how my simple calcification that was to be straightforward  excision  and rads turned  into what it did!
Posts.Title: Results of surgery

Posts.Content: Fanflippintastic news, woo hoo . Xx
Posts.Title: I have my results

Posts.Content: Hi suzie02, i am 8 weeks post rads and still have a swollen boob (nearly have a matching pair so every cloud!!) Pains at the booster site/side of boob and a really sore shoulder. Had oncology  appt last week and they had no concerns. Hope you feel more comfy soon but to contact your team if worried xxxx
Posts.Title: Breast pain (STILL) 7/8 weeks after RT anyone ?

Posts.Content: Hi Chelsea bun, I've used all clear twice and they did cover the breast cancer as a pre-existing condition xx
Posts.Title: Travel insurance (another one!)

Posts.Content: In fact I was panicking that much I have just ran a quote  :)  "We will cover you for claims associated with those pre-existing  medical  conditions  or  disabilities  you disclosed to us and we accepted in writing. We will  not  cover  you  for  claims  associated  with  preexisting  medical  conditions  that  you  did  not  disclose to us and we did not accept in writing. You must tell us about ALL medical conditions for which you answer yes under 1 – 4 above" My cancer was node positive and had the full treatment malarkey. X
Posts.Title: Travel insurance (another one!)

Posts.Content: I think I need to have a real good look at future policies as I rang and asked the guy specifically if I needed to cancel due to a reoccurance etc would i be covered and was categorically told yes as long as it was fully declared!! X
Posts.Title: Travel insurance (another one!)

Posts.Content: Congratulations hope you had a fab day x
Posts.Title: Celebration today ...

Posts.Content: Been thinking of yesterday's results  and getting a bit angry wondering  how a 30mm idc wasn't palpable,  didn't show up on mammogram  (few flipping micro calcs), utrasound.or a fair few biopsies. The estimate area was about 15mm but that was thought to vontain only a small foci of idc.  Probably  simple answer but sitting wondering!
Posts.Title: how can you not detect a 30 mm tumour!

Posts.Content: Julia, you are right I know. Think I am just working through things in my head to put them in the box of can't change things so  put the lid on and carry on.  In some ways (sounding a bit of a drama lama! ) it's like models they use to explain the grieving process and I felt I had done that but have now gone back to the anger stage.   Dogs don't know what's hit them today we will be walking for miles. Have a good weekend x
Posts.Title: how can you not detect a 30 mm tumour!

Posts.Content: I had semi permanent tattoos done pre chemo which I was delighted with. They did them slightly thicker than my natural brows which were a bit sparse from overplucking when I was younger (!). However my brows have grown back thicker than before so I would personally wait otherwise you could have brows very out of line. Xx
Posts.Title: Microblading eyebrows post-chemo?

Posts.Content: Dulcie  blimey that was a beastie, you are not preaching at all you are quite right and we should grab what we can.  The dogs have legs 2 inches shorter and the human pups are moaning but a good walk finished  with a stop at the pub worked wonders. I feel I am just struggling at times with the fact I had the biopsies to a contained area with no problem identified and it was only the fact the haematoma didn't go down that i went back to the gp and everyone kept reiterating  they didn't think it was a problem, so shocker followed by shocker! Anyway nothing I can do just need to work through this but if the journey.  Thank you to all that have replied  x
Posts.Title: how can you not detect a 30 mm tumour!

Posts.Content: Sorry if this sounds a daft question but why is there an increased risk of breast cancer in the other breast  if the first tumour fully treated, I know it's not common but have been pondering the whys and how's? X
Posts.Title: Increaseed risk of cancer in other breast -why?

Posts.Content: Lol for a change it's not something I am worrying about  just pondering xx
Posts.Title: Increaseed risk of cancer in other breast -why?

Posts.Content: Awh Zanib I was wondering how you were getting on, your mamma sounds wonderful and I am glad that you are getting support xxx
Posts.Title: please explain

Posts.Content: Looking at my reply not sure that makes sense! The only areas that get a double dose are those that need a boost and not everyone needs this.
Posts.Title: double rads?

Posts.Content: Hi millie,  I would contact your breast care nurse to discuss it further if your not clear. I had a positive sentinal  node 1/2 removed and i was given a choice of either axillary clearance or rads to axilla. I went for rads (finished  october) and although my shoulder /under  arm is a bit tight at the moment it hasn't been a big problem.  Good luck with whatever you decide x
Posts.Title: double rads?

Posts.Content: Hi millie63, I was given aquamax cream which us similar to aqueous (but feels better) and washed with non perfumed/coloured  soap as advised by my unit didn't get any problems skin wise apart from being a bit pink and had any itchy rash on my chest which they gave me hydrocortisone  cream.   Aqueous  cream is horrible to wash with! X
Posts.Title: creams to use

Posts.Content: Hiya yes it was the breast and axilla with 8 boosts to the tumour bed.  it's all done as one but carefully calculated in the planning do it only goes to the areas that need it so no double doses (unless boost needed),  the machine is set and you are jiggled  very carefully to ensure the correct positioning.  X
Posts.Title: double rads?

Posts.Content: Well done lynn and congratulations, woo hoo x
Posts.Title: Finished at last!!!!

Posts.Content: Jane you are being awfully hard on yourself why would anyone hate you you've just been human that's all.  I don't have expierience of diep but lots of others have and am sure will comment, however instead of a worry frenzy could you call your bcn and chat it through? Sending a hug your way xxx
Posts.Title: massive panic! please don't hate me.

Posts.Content: Thanks Lynn is was a relief even more so as no one made me feel a right neurotic idiot . I will see what oncologist says as currently popping more pain killers than when having treatment! Cheers Helen  x
Posts.Title: Pain after chemo finished?

Posts.Content: I completed chemo  (3 fect, 2 docetaxol and 3 paclitaxol) nearly 3 weeks ago and am still having pain mainly across shoulders,  neck, arms down into hands.  I am going back for the results of ct scan done due to my arm swelling this week so will raise with oncologist. Did anyone else have this? I am starting anastrozle next week and don't need any additional aches and pains! X
Posts.Title: Pain after chemo finished?

Posts.Content: Good luck x
Posts.Title: one year review tomorrow

Posts.Content: Couldnt feel a lump and it was 34mm!
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Best to ask the mammograms are generally the remit of the surgeon (well they are here! ) and my  oncologist isn't interested in anything to do with screening. Ccc
Posts.Title: Onco app & mammogram

Posts.Content: Great news zanib, onwards and upwards x
Posts.Title: Half way

Posts.Content: Yvonne,  fabulous news
Posts.Title: Good news on results

Posts.Content: Yey that is great news   xxx
Posts.Title: STABLE.........

Posts.Content: I dont know about henna but I had semi permanent  eyebrow  tattoo just before chemo and have been delighted with the result.  You would need to check with your oncologist.
Posts.Title: henna eyebrows

Posts.Content: I am sure someone with more knowledge will come along but my understanding of HER 2 is that there are very effective treatments ghats are used and that your results are very positive in relation to diagnosis  etc.   Sending hugs   Helen x
Posts.Title: Got myself worked up about HER2 + status

Posts.Content: Well done Fiona what an achievement, i think it must be a relief but a but scary at the same time?xxx
Posts.Title: End of treatment....!

Posts.Content: Great news skye woohoo :) x
Posts.Title: Happy news....

Posts.Content: Hi rosie may the waiting is a crappy difficult  time and nothing really makes it better you just manage it day to day  (blimey that sounds depressing  ). I am 48 and was diagnosed 2 weeks ago (a very big bolt out of the blue)my children are 10, we didn't say anything much until we had an idea of what was happening and then as someone else has said gave age appropriate honest info. I found keeping super busy (the dogs legs are 2 inches shorter)  to occupy the brain space and carrying on as normal work wise worked for me.   Right down any questions and don't be afraid to ask or challenge anything you are unclear about and use the fabulous support and expertise here. Hugs Helen
Posts.Title: Awaiting results of biopsy

Posts.Content: Great news you must have felt so relieved x
Posts.Title: Guilty meltdown.

Posts.Content: Woo hoo, congratulations  x
Posts.Title: RIP Cancer 12/04/15---11/02/16 I'm there! LAST TREATMENT TODAY, No...

Posts.Content: I would like to add the how many clothes you can remove when hoovering event, the kids say its lime being on holiday :;
Posts.Title: NOT Pink and Fluffy! RETURNS....

Posts.Content: Hi Cec , sorry you are joining our not so little club. You are not selfish at all you have just been given life changing news and everyone here can relate to the way you are feeling at the moment. It may not feel like it at present but it does get better you just have to work  through things 1 bit at a time.  As others have said no one is "brave" as such as we have no choice,  the "brave" face is generally for others whilst our insides are in turmoil, however, we learn to deal with things in our own way. Accept/ask for help with practical things, your daughter will learn to cope. I used to wake up every morning thinking everything was fine and then the reality would hit me again, I don't do that now but I am not sure  when that stopped it just did at some point. Please vent, rant or whatever on the forum it is a great support, sending a hug x
Posts.Title: How are you all so brave, I've just been diagnosed

Posts.Content: I think they mean me standing there with not alot on!
Posts.Title: NOT Pink and Fluffy! RETURNS....

Posts.Content: Thank you, its the quickness of the scan ( just waiting for a  time)  and seeing consultant with results wed thats worrying me!x
Posts.Title: In a right tizz now!

Posts.Content: Hi I am due my 3rd beginning of September and have had no issues xx
Posts.Title: Bones

Posts.Content: Back to the hospital  yesterday as this flippin arm is still  swelling (also bit on chest/neck) after picc removal. Saw doc and am now waiting for ct of chest and liver and to see consultant next week for results.  Now in all likely hood it will be fine but combined with going back to the breast clinic for the "something" in the boob on that side now got my knickers in a right knot,  grrrr.  xxx
Posts.Title: In a right tizz now!

Posts.Content: Fabulous  news thats what we like to hear xxx
Posts.Title: In panic mode

Posts.Content: Hi sue, it is a bit if a shock when the game plan changes  isn't it!  I had a 15 mm malignant "area" of dcis and of grade 2 idc so plan was surgery and radiotherapy.   Unfortunately the surgery showed it to be a 30mm invasive cancer that had also buggered off to the axilla so chemo recommended. I was devastated.  I am having 6 cycles of FEC- t .  my 2nd treatment tomorrow and whilst not looking forward to it,  is doable and had picc put in today.    The fear of the unknown is the worst thing and I am not so terrified this time around and I have felt really good this last week.  Good luck x
Posts.Title: About to start chemo and so worried

Posts.Content: I am due first mammogram post bc the beginning of january.  The mammogram that i had when i went back with a lump at the biopsy site done 3/4 months earlier didnt show any change from the previous one the change was picked up on ultrasound and the lump biopsied. Has anyone requested/had additional screening eg ultrasound? Tbh iam not bothered about have to pay for it i am just lacking faith in mammograms, they highlighted calcifications  but not a 34mm tumour!
Posts.Title: Screening after bresst cancer

Posts.Content: I thought i had better start checking the good boob and think i can feel *something*  in the inner quadrant but only when i a sitting up with arm up not lying down. although  i am 49 i have been menopausal for approx 5  years (hrt stopped when diagnosed January so my understanding is that boobs dont tend to be lumpy like pre menopausal women.  My cancer was identified on screening so i didnt initally find a lump so not quite surewhat it would feel like and the last mammo in december  was clear (not that reassurred as it didnt identify a 3cm cancer in the other boob). I have just finished chemo so what would the chances be of a problem in the other boob, I know the answer is to  see my gp but feel like i am faffing over something that is probably normal!!!! Arghhhh x
Posts.Title: I know what the answer is but.....

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia i am going to ask and see what happens. Lainy r its just another thing to worry about isnt it, i had an oncology appt today and asked the specialist nurse who didnt think it unreasonable so going to discuss with BCN (havent prrsecuted her for a while :) ) x
Posts.Title: Screening after bresst cancer

Posts.Content: Lovely GP rang back to say she had spoken to surgeons secretary and would fax referral to be seen under 2 week rule so will get an appoint soon. Haven't said anything  to hubby as can't see the point in worrying him  for something that is likely to be nothing. X
Posts.Title: I know what the answer is but.....

Posts.Content: nicolaangie66 It is a bit of a shock, and yes how rude.....I a thinking same as you, my appointment with oncologist is mid August so should know a bit more then. Best wishes for your treatment, and keep in touch xx Nicola Good luck with your oncology appointment you are right to listen and make a decision  that you feel comfortable with. My oncologist was very good in explaining  the pros/cons of chemo and the benefit he felt it would give me and for me the % benefit was good enough for me to say yes x
Posts.Title: Lymph Node positive what happens next??

Posts.Content: Been to the gp who could feel the "something" but thinks it is normal breast tissue but that it needed checking so is going to contact the hospital and didn't think I was a div at all  x
Posts.Title: I know what the answer is but.....

Posts.Content: Ah karen,  thank you for your lovely reply. He is a very good husband,  dad and friend  always has been. We are very opposite  in our personalities which up to know has worked very well  and I think took us through 24 yes of marriage. There was quite a few of us that married around the same time and we are the only couple still together  and I think at the back of my mind I worry that this flippin nightmare will do the same to us.  We are so lucky that we have a very good family  (my inlaws) and I have been so moved by the kindness  of friends, neighbours and parents at school it has made the practicalities  so much easier.  He did say to me that how people have been saying that "I am your rock but I am not I've let you down"  and I have pointed  out that I don't need a rock I just need him their with me. The antidepressants  will take a while to kick in and I am hoping that he will also think about counselling.   The things that are sent to test us hey? X
Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: I had wle/mammoplasty/snb pm on 24/2 for grade 2 idc with some dcis.  This came out of the blue following benign biopsies  of microcalcifications last september of which a lump remained at the biopsy site, that is what sent me back to the breast clinic in December. No one thought there was going to be a problem and in total I ended up with 6  biopsies before surgery. I built myself up for the results last Friday  but unfortunately they weren't ready so appointment rescheduled for this Friday.    Now starting to wobble so badly that my GP has prescribed low dose diazepam and I feel a right pathetic person for not coping so well at present  as there are many people in much more difficult positions than me. I am generally one of the most resillient people going so annoyed with myself at the moment.  The plan has always been surgery  followed by radiotherapy/hormone therapy and I am now terrified  that the results will change this, margins won't be clear, grade 3 instead of 2, the weak ER+ will be negative,  I could go on and on! Sorry for the ramble I think part of the problem  is that no one expected  the cancer so I am not quite believing the results will be what was expected either if that makes sense?  Helen
Posts.Title: bit of a ramble starting to wobble!

Posts.Content: Thank you for your kind replies and yes I think I am being to hard on myself!  I am a hardy bird  which is what makes  this so difficult  and yes I am the one that everyone  brings the I'd problems  which to be honest hasn't been a problem till now.  However,  I needed to hear that it's OK to feel a right pathetic numpty rather than try and soldier on.  I met with my lovely  work friend who didn't faff sround but after  me wittering on about what could be  said "I don't understand it all but I hope you get the results of the cancer that you want " which we looked at each other and burst out laughing , priceless.  Thank you macmillan towers xxx
Posts.Title: bit of a ramble starting to wobble!

Posts.Content: Awh Chris it sounds like you have had a shockingly  rough time please don't apologise for feeling negative that is what the forum is for.  It is extremely unhelpful when family,  friends  tell you it's all going to be fine but they don't know what else to say and I think it makes them feel better when you feel like thumping them (or maybe that was is just me  ). My hubby has been a right ostrich since my cancer diagnosis I feel like screaming at him sometimes so heaven knows  what he would be like trying to cope with your current situation, your hubby it's probably trying to deal with it the best way he can which I know us not very helpful to you. I am wishing you the best of luck for a positive outcome today, if it is not the news you would wish for you will have treatment plan and a way forward. I do believe  that whatever we have to face it is "easier" once you know and have a plan to move forward, the waiting is truly awful. Sending a big cyber hug xxx Helen
Posts.Title: HAS IT SPREAD - TODAYS THE DAY

Posts.Content: Desicion  made will ring gp tomorrow even if i look like a bit of a div! Purplediva my operated boob is lumpy  n bumpy due to surgery and o believe it takes quite a while to settle down,the rads can also alter the breast tissue xx
Posts.Title: I know what the answer is but.....

Posts.Content: All ok, phew and not made to feel a neurotic idiot at all! Dr did say the hormone therapy can change the breast tissue also so at least I have an idea of what it feels like before starting the anastrozle (deep joy!) next week x
Posts.Title: I know what the answer is but.....

Posts.Content: Ive decided to take a every thing i  moderation approach and have switched to using dr organic shampoo, yes to carrots or palmers scalp/hair conditioner  as i found ordinary  irritated my scalp, sanex stick deodorant which is good but not sure how it will work out in the summer and palmers body lotion and concentrated cream for hands. Will be switching face cream when simple runs out and am looking for a good bodywash as dont like the sanex. The make is more difficult up as i like the products i use and think the other changes cover bigger areas so can live with non paraben/sls free unless anyone can recommend some good ones? X
Posts.Title: Parabens, etc

Posts.Content: Thank you for everyone's replies, the gp started hubby on antidepressants and will see  him again jn 2 weeks,  he declined  the offer of counselling which I am cross about but have said nothing as he has made the first steps on his own which us the important thing. I am just very frustrated  with him (angry to) x
Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: Hi Nicola,  same here my tumour was grade 2, 30mm, er 6, her - which was rude enough to have nipped off as a macrometastasis to 1 lymph node. It was a bit if a shock as the lymph node didn't show on ultrasound.  The recommendation from the mdt was for radiotherapy to the axilla rather than clearance and I have been back to discuss  it again with my surgeon  after the oncologist  raised clearance. My surgeon is adamant that further surgery will not add benefit. Ism coming to the end if chemo soon and have an appointment with oncologist you discuss but I think I will be going with radiotherapy rather than surgery. Hope that helps x
Posts.Title: Lymph Node positive what happens next??

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed in feb and then unexpectedly had chemo thrown into the mix March and my husband has not coped with my diagnosis  which has frustrated  me at times.  However, following a bit of a blip yesterday  about wigs/ hair he has finally admitted he isnt coping and is making a gp appointment Monday. I think it's more than "not coping" and he seems clinically  depressed, in fact i was quite scared at some of the things he has been thinking of!  He seems and says he feels better now he has admitted  it and is taking some action. Has anyone else been in this position, if do how did you get through?
Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: Ah karen,  thank you for your lovely reply. He is a very good husband,  dad and friend  always has been. We are very opposite  in our personalities which up to know has worked very well  and I think took us through 24 yes of marriage. There was quite a few of us that married around the same time and we are the only couple still together  and I think at the back of my mind I worry that this flippin nightmare will do the same to us.  We are so lucky that we have a very good family  (my inlaws) and I have been so moved by the kindness  of friends, neighbours and parents at school it has made the practicalities  so much easier.  He did say to me that how people have been saying that "I am your rock but I am not I've let you down"  and I have pointed  out that I don't need a rock I just need him their with me. The antidepressants  will take a while to kick in and I am hoping that he will also think about counselling.   The things that are sent to test us hey? X
Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: Thank you for posting that is so helpful  as I was looking online and saw bamboo caps but didn't  know if they did make much of a difference,  added to shopping list x
Posts.Title: A comfortable find!

Posts.Content: Thank you for everyone's replies, the gp started hubby on antidepressants and will see  him again jn 2 weeks,  he declined  the offer of counselling which I am cross about but have said nothing as he has made the first steps on his own which us the important thing. I am just very frustrated  with him (angry to) x
Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed in feb and then unexpectedly had chemo thrown into the mix March and my husband has not coped with my diagnosis  which has frustrated  me at times.  However, following a bit of a blip yesterday  about wigs/ hair he has finally admitted he isnt coping and is making a gp appointment Monday. I think it's more than "not coping" and he seems clinically  depressed, in fact i was quite scared at some of the things he has been thinking of!  He seems and says he feels better now he has admitted  it and is taking some action. Has anyone else been in this position, if do how did you get through?
Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: Heard last night that someone I know is seriously ill in hospital with pancreatic cancer, they have 2 children in Junior school as I do.  I was sitting a few feet away in the oncology centre last year but its never been mentioned and I have respected that.  I feel so incredibly sad for everyone but also very lucky ( and a bit selfish) that my cancer was a breast cancer there are so many treatment options and that the prognosis is so much better. Don't know why i am posting this here and dont want to depress anyone further but its probably because my hubby doesn't understand how it makes me feel but also the realisation that after coming through treatment that the future is much brighter than sometimes it feels xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling sad but lucky!

Posts.Content: Hi pmummy,  I had fec so ec with the 5fu added in. The nausea was a problem for me and so they gave me emend for the second cycle which  helped.  I used to feel fuzzy before a got out of the chair and felt like I had a really bad hangover, horrible taste and generally bleugh it took to about day 7 before it started to lift and felt ok if abit tired from day 10 onwards. The gscf injections made me ache.  I took all the meds offerred as I felt so rough and nibbled ginger bicuits/tea (i cant look at ginger know!). Hang in n there it does get better and as Carolyn suggests hop over to the Jan chemo club xxxc
Posts.Title: Side effects of EC chemotherapy?

Posts.Content: I managed 12mths on anastrozole and couldn't bear the pain I was experiencing so oncologist switched me to exemestane.  While I still shuffle when I get up and have some joint pain it is far more tolerable than the anastrozole so for me the change was a good choice. I Just switched straight over xxx
Posts.Title: Has anyone stopped taking letrozole and switched to other aromatase...

Posts.Content: Thank you all, unfortunately another person was taken to soon today and I feel so sad for the children and everyone else left behind.  The only consolation is that it was not prolonged xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling sad but lucky!

Posts.Content: This a question iam going to ask my bcn when i see her next. I was menopausal at 44 and on hrt until diagnosis.  I presumed i would be given one when starting on the anastrozole but i was started on adcal and zoledronic acid at the same time so i dont know if they do one if already on treatment?
Posts.Title: Bone density scan, should I have had one?

Posts.Content: I still use a razor as i have also never cut under my arm, however i have found that since treatment finished i only need to do the "good" arm once every preston guild and the rads seem to have taken care of the other side :) . Xxx
Posts.Title: Under arm hair.......

Posts.Content: I recently booked a holiday and was a bit stuck on that question especially as it's going on for 5 yrs!  I rang and they said it wasn't a problem as it's routine screening, that was with Allclear who weren't a bad price at all so i would ring and check xx
Posts.Title: Travel insurance medical screening question
